item.description:
@Freddy1990 wrote:

Mopman:

uh are you sure they dont just use winelib

I’m not, all I know is that the api is the same, well, it’s missing a lot of stuff, but it’s supposed to act the same on all platforms

i think a better solution is to use a ‘cross-platform’ language…

i don’t know, maybe java?

item.title: Jret
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Freddy1990, post:23, topic:302221”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=398549.msg2958790#msg2958790 date=1253027197]

Hmm, that’s bs… And I’ve been working on a port for SCAR, but atm FPC isn’t good enough to make it work properly cross-platform, my code compiles, but for some reason it doesn’t work on linux… So I simply can’t continue until they make the cross-platform api implementation in FPC work properly… Also, porting a program as huge as SCAR isn’t something you just do, it’s a bitch to do once it’s written… This project I can keep easily portable from the start, that’s why my cross-platform version of SCAR is a rewrite…

And well, if I can’t port it, so be it, my software is closed source, you know I won’t debate that.

If it compiles I would think all you would have to do is write new routines to move the mouse, send keys, and perhaps pick colors with X instead of using the win32 API. This would also give you the added benefit of making it work on any UNIX system, like Mac as well.

KMouseTool is a program you can look at the source for for the mouse movement and clicking. xvkbd to send key events (while googling for that website I actually found a linux auto-typer for RS, who knew?). KColorChooser seems a good place to get color picking code.

That is assuming your script engine and such works, but I don’t see any reason it wouldn’t, does it? If everything else works and you can give me an interface or something similar (method signatures would be fine too, whatever) I would even be willing to write the code / methods for you so we can get a working SCAR for linux.
[/quote]
The FPC api is supposed to work cross-platform… It emulates the win32 api on all platforms, but it doesn’t work, again, that’s the problem…[/quote]

They try to emulate the win32 API on all platforms in a separate effort from WINE which does the same thing? That sounds like a huge waste of time. Have you tried compiling with the wine libs?

Read full topic

item.title: Jret
item.dc:creator: @Freddy1990 Freddy1990
item.description:
@Freddy1990 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:21, topic:302221”][quote author=Freddy1990 link=topic=398549.msg2957973#msg2957973 date=1252964341]
Hmm, that’s bs… And I’ve been working on a port for SCAR, but atm FPC isn’t good enough to make it work properly cross-platform, my code compiles, but for some reason it doesn’t work on linux… So I simply can’t continue until they make the cross-platform api implementation in FPC work properly… Also, porting a program as huge as SCAR isn’t something you just do, it’s a bitch to do once it’s written… This project I can keep easily portable from the start, that’s why my cross-platform version of SCAR is a rewrite…

And well, if I can’t port it, so be it, my software is closed source, you know I won’t debate that.
[/quote]

If it compiles I would think all you would have to do is write new routines to move the mouse, send keys, and perhaps pick colors with X instead of using the win32 API. This would also give you the added benefit of making it work on any UNIX system, like Mac as well.

KMouseTool is a program you can look at the source for for the mouse movement and clicking. xvkbd to send key events (while googling for that website I actually found a linux auto-typer for RS, who knew?). KColorChooser seems a good place to get color picking code.

That is assuming your script engine and such works, but I don’t see any reason it wouldn’t, does it? If everything else works and you can give me an interface or something similar (method signatures would be fine too, whatever) I would even be willing to write the code / methods for you so we can get a working SCAR for linux.[/quote]
The FPC api is supposed to work cross-platform… It emulates the win32 api on all platforms, but it doesn’t work, again, that’s the problem…

Read full topic

item.title: Jret
item.dc:creator: @ownagesbot ownagesbot
item.description:
@ownagesbot wrote:

[quote=“yakman, post:13, topic:302221”]how are you meant to reverse engineer java if you dont know java?

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reverse_engineering#Reverse_engineering_of_software[/quote]My point exactly. How the fuck are people supposed to know what they’re writing a script for if they don’t even know anything about the language. And if you want to have any half useful scripts, you’d most likely want to part/fully deobfuscate it, which isn’t exactly easy, or a small job.

Read full topic

And well, if I can’t port it, so be it, my software is closed source, you know I won’t debate that.[/quote]

If it compiles I would think all you would have to do is write new routines to move the mouse, send keys, and perhaps pick colors with X instead of using the win32 API. This would also give you the added benefit of making it work on any UNIX system, like Mac as well.

KMouseTool is a program you can look at the source for for the mouse movement and clicking. xvkbd to send key events (while googling for that website I actually found a linux auto-typer for RS, who knew?). KColorChooser seems a good place to get color picking code.

That is assuming your script engine and such works, but I don’t see any reason it wouldn’t, does it? If everything else works and you can give me an interface or something similar (method signatures would be fine too, whatever) I would even be willing to write the code / methods for you so we can get a working SCAR for linux.

item.description:
@Freddy1990 wrote:

oksuper_:

Sorry but this is pretty pointless, but then again I am in no position to declare something pointless seeing as I have never done anything that anyone else would consider worth-while.

Maybe… As for now I’m going to write this bytecode library first, building it so it doesn’t annoy me at some times like BCEL does, lol

item.title: Jret
item.dc:creator: @Freddy1990 Freddy1990
item.description:
@Freddy1990 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:17, topic:302221”][quote author=Freddy1990 link=topic=398549.msg2957832#msg2957832 date=1252959605]

Will you have the ability to compile this for other operating systems besides windows? Or is it going to be another closed source, single platform app?

I’m probably going to create a port for Linux/Mac with FPC, the app will look different then though, another problem is that i don’t have a suited script engine for linux/mac, so it might lose a few features there, dunno, I’ll do what i can though… If I port it to .NET I could possibly compile it cross-platform with Delphi Prism/Mono though… But by the time it’s fully completed, CodeGear will probably have finished their cross-platform version of Delphi… Basically, the whole thing should be easily portable, aside from the GUI and the script engine, but I’m fairly confident that the author of the engine I’m using would probably update it to work cross-platform… All of my work will be slowing down soon as I’m going to college…

It sounds like it might not be too big of a job to port, but are you going to release the source so it can be done?

I’m not sure why I’d need to release the source to port it?
[/quote]

Well, you’ve been promising to port SCAR for ages, so lets be honest, to get it done you will have to release the source so someone else can do it.[/quote]
Hmm, that’s bs… And I’ve been working on a port for SCAR, but atm FPC isn’t good enough to make it work properly cross-platform, my code compiles, but for some reason it doesn’t work on linux… So I simply can’t continue until they make the cross-platform api implementation in FPC work properly… Also, porting a program as huge as SCAR isn’t something you just do, it’s a bitch to do once it’s written… This project I can keep easily portable from the start, that’s why my cross-platform version of SCAR is a rewrite…

And well, if I can’t port it, so be it, my software is closed source, you know I won’t debate that.

Read full topic

item.title: Jret

item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Freddy1990, post:16, topic:302221”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=398549.msg2957830#msg2957830 date=1252959533]

Will you have the ability to compile this for other operating systems besides windows? Or is it going to be another closed source, single platform app?

I’m probably going to create a port for Linux/Mac with FPC, the app will look different then though, another problem is that i don’t have a suited script engine for linux/mac, so it might lose a few features there, dunno, I’ll do what i can though… If I port it to .NET I could possibly compile it cross-platform with Delphi Prism/Mono though… But by the time it’s fully completed, CodeGear will probably have finished their cross-platform version of Delphi… Basically, the whole thing should be easily portable, aside from the GUI and the script engine, but I’m fairly confident that the author of the engine I’m using would probably update it to work cross-platform… All of my work will be slowing down soon as I’m going to college…

It sounds like it might not be too big of a job to port, but are you going to release the source so it can be done?
[/quote]
I’m not sure why I’d need to release the source to port it?[/quote]

Well, you’ve been promising to port SCAR for ages, so lets be honest, to get it done you will have to release the source so someone else can do it.

Read full topic

item.title: Jret
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

how are you meant to reverse engineer java if you dont know java?

en.wikipedia.org

Reverse engineering

Reverse engineering, also called back engineering, is the process by which a man-made object is deconstructed to reveal its designs, architecture, or to extract knowledge from the object; similar to scientific research, the only difference being that scientific research is about a natural phenomenon.:3 Reverse engineering is applicable in the fields of mechanical engineering, electronic engineering, software engineering, chemical engineering, and systems biology. There are many reasons for perf...

Read full topic

item.title: Jret
item.dc:creator: @Freddy1990 Freddy1990
item.description:
@Freddy1990 wrote:

Hmm, I’ve taken a look at the classfile specifications, and it does indeed not look that complicated, I wrote a (de)compiler for 8xp files for the TI-84 calculator, this doesn’t look that much harder… I’m going to give writing that library a chance, who knows, maybe I’ll make it better than BCEL Writing it completely natively in Delphi will also increase the performance like 10fold or so, bridging trough JNI isn’t exactly speed efficient

Read full topic

item.title: Jret
item.dc:creator: @Freddy1990 Freddy1990
item.description:
@Freddy1990 wrote:

Unhandled:

I’d say it’s a lot more interesting to write your own bytecode library. This just sounds like a massive hack job. I’ve written a (partial) bytecode library in C# which is easily scriptable using ironpython or ironruby.

Is it that easy to write a bytecode lib? If it were I wouldn’t mind giving it a try, lol, I’m already porting parts of BCEL to native code to avoid extra use of JNI =/

Read full topic

item.title: Jret
item.dc:creator: @Freddy1990 Freddy1990
item.description:
@Freddy1990 wrote:

Moparisthebest:

Will you have the ability to compile this for other operating systems besides windows? Or is it going to be another closed source, single platform app?

I’m probably going to create a port for Linux/Mac with FPC, the app will look different then though, another problem is that i don’t have a suited script engine for linux/mac, so it might lose a few features there, dunno, I’ll do what i can though… If I port it to .NET I could possibly compile it cross-platform with Delphi Prism/Mono though… But by the time it’s fully completed, CodeGear will probably have finished their cross-platform version of Delphi… Basically, the whole thing should be easily portable, aside from the GUI and the script engine, but I’m fairly confident that the author of the engine I’m using would probably update it to work cross-platform… All of my work will be slowing down soon as I’m going to college…

ownagesbot:

If people don’t know java, they’re hardly going to be able to write any kind of updater, even if it is just a script. Are you going to handle obfuscation? I’d go with java.

Why would I need to handle obfuscation?

EDIT: Btw, it rly isn’t messy, just a lot of work for me to keep track of resources and crap, but you won’t notice any of that at the front-end…

Read full topic

item.title: Jret
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

This is actually a pretty neat idea, scripting updating in pascal is an interesting excercise, although I have to believe that somewhere there exists a pascal script engine written in java, which would make this much easier and less, messy.

Will you have the ability to compile this for other operating systems besides windows? Or is it going to be another closed source, single platform app?

Read full topic

item.title: Jret
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

writing an updater for a cheat for a java game and not knowing java

set sail for fail

Read full topic

item.title: Jret
item.dc:creator: @Freddy1990 Freddy1990
item.description:
@Freddy1990 wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:2, topic:302221”]why not just use java

ps bcel sux[/quote]
I want to make writing updaters more accessible to people who don’t know Java, also it’s a good exercise in memory management and I have a very powerful script engine I can use in Delphi, I cbf to write one in java I’ll probably add in support for more libraries like ASM once I’m done with BCEL, but I started with that because I know my way around it, never took the time to look into how ASM and such work

Read full topic
